description: Brief review of High School calculus, applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, Taylor's theorem. Use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.
name: CALCULUS I

values.comments:
Calculus Part I (Math 104) begins with a brief review of high school calculus. The course then teaches students about the applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series and Taylor's theorem.  In addition, students use symbolic manipulation and graphics software in this course. 

Students found the content of this calculus course to be difficult, but they described the class as “very organized.”  One student said, “The examples done in class are very simple as compared to the online homework.” Some thought the examples were too similar to the book's as well.

Students thought that Professor Jankowski was an excellent, clear, and very accessible professor. They found that he was always willing to answer any and all questions in and outside of class.  Professor Jankowski “went beyond what was discussed in the book and showed a wider applicability of the material discussed in class. “ His sense of humor was also appreciated by the students, with one saying it made the lectures of somewhat dry material more “bearable.”

Math 104 assumes that students have taken AB Calculus or the equivalent.  Students who have not had AB Calculus or did poorly in AB Calculus should take MATH 103, which provides an introduction to calculus.  There is no prerequisite for this course. This course fulfills the Formal Reasoning requirement. Engineering students are encouraged to register for the 007 lecture and group 7 recitations.  In regards to the difficulty of the course, students said Professor Jankowski’s tests were very “doable.” They said Professor Jankowski is fair and not the type to deliberately give students a hard time with difficult problems.  In addition, students said that grading in this course was quite lenient.  Students are allowed to drop two of their lowest quizzes, and the tests that students do well on are given more weight in their final grade.  However, one student did recommend taking advantage of the outside tutoring system to ensure their success in this course.

Calculus Part I (Math 104) begins with a brief review of high school calculus. The course then teaches students about the applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series and Taylor's theorem.  In addition, students use symbolic manipulation and graphics software in this course. 

	Students thought the course moved very fast, and students felt that there was a huge discrepancy between lecture and recitation. 

Professor Rimmer is widely available to all students seeking help. His approach to the material is very clear to understand, and he keeps the subject matter interesting. Dr. Rimmer cares a lot about his students' success both in and out of the classroom.  His assessments and grading are both extremely fair.  His teaching style is a good pace for people who understand the reasoning behind the math formulas.  He makes a large lecture hall seem like a small classroom by addressing any questions a student has during class. One student said, “Professor Rimmer turned me from hating calculus to loving it.”

Math 104 assumes that students have had AB Calculus or the equivalent.  Students who have not had AB Calculus or did poorly in AB Calculus should take MATH 103, which provides an introduction to calculus.  There is no prerequisite for this course. Engineering students are encouraged to register for the 007 lecture and group 7 recitations. This is a Formal Reasoning course.   Some students said the course was difficult, and unfairly tested.  His midterms are incredibly tough. Each one is curved but the curves are incredibly tough to beat as there is a wide variety of students in the large class.

Calculus Part I (Math 104) begins with a brief review of high school calculus. The course then teaches students about the applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series and Taylor's theorem.  In addition, students use symbolic manipulation and graphics software in this course. 

	Students thought this was a great course for anyone who is interested in math. 

	Students said Professor Jauregui is fantastic. He is able to clearly and effectively communicate the topic at hand and stimulate student interest.  He is also very good at answering students' questions during lecture, doing more examples if necessary, and being available outside of class for extra help. He knows everyone's name, is really engaging, nice, and never pretentious. One student said, “He emailed me when I did really well on a midterm to say how proud he was of me—that’s  a great teacher.”

Math 104 assumes that students have had AB Calculus or the equivalent.  Students who have not had AB Calculus or did poorly in AB Calculus should take MATH 103, which provides an introduction to calculus.  There is no prerequisite for this course. Engineering students are encouraged to register for the 007 lecture and group 7 recitations. This is a Formal Reasoning course.  Students thought this course was difficult.
